title: KNOW YOUR RASPBERRIES - How to get a BUMPER crop from your homegrown raspberries

subtasks: Differentiate between primocanes and floricanes
Identify signs of silvering and brittleness in second-year growth
Recognize primocane growth stages (green and thick vs. light brown)
Select appropriate Raspberry varieties (summer-bearing, autumn-bearing, everbearing)
Plan for different harvest times (early spring, late spring/early summer, late summer/autumn)
Remove old floricanes each year
Retain and stake primocanes for next year's floricanes
Support vigorous primocanes with stakes
Ensure soil moisture levels are optimal
Watch for signs of dehydration or overwatering
Use foliar feeding method for nutrient absorption
Maintain a sunny planting location
Keep soil well-drained with organic matter

tasks.task: Knowing When to Care for Raspberries. Under that, breaking it down into:
Knowing When to Care for Raspberries

subtasks: Understand that raspberries produce in spring, early summer, late summer
Identify primocane growth in spring and select five strong canes to stake
Mow down the previous year's canes if growing autumn-bearing raspberries
Remove old floricanes immediately
Stake new primocanes
Harvest berries as they ripen
Check soil moisture daily and adjust
Prepare plants for dormancy (reduce watering)
Consider pruning in depth if time permits

tasks.task: Identify and Differentiate Primocanes and Floricanes
Plan for pruning and harvest timing based on variety
Monitor soil moisture and adjust watering
Differentiate between primocanes and floricanes and perform pruning accordingly
Plan and manage harvest based on variety selection
** Differences between primocanes and floricanes; knowing their growth habits. (Saw that many times in the video, but maybe one task.)
** Removing old canes (floricanes) and supporting new primocanes. (This is a key physical action.)
** Monitoring soil moisture and adjusting watering as needed. The video mentions the leaves drooping or burning as signs.
** Using a foliar feed method for nutrients.

subtasks: Differentiate between primocanes and floricanes
Identify signs of overwintered growth
Choose summer-bearing, autumn-bearing, or everbearing raspberries
Remove old floricanes each year
Stake new primocanes for support
Check soil moisture and adjust watering based on signs
Mix and apply a foliar feeding solution
Identify primocanes (green, thick stems) and floricanes (silvering, brittle)
Recognize the ripening cycle of different varieties (early spring, late spring/summer, late summer/fall)
Choose between summer-bearing, autumn-bearing, or everbearing raspberries based on desired harvest times
Cut down old floricanes near the base in winter
Stake new primocane growth to support their growth cycle
Check soil moisture by observing leaf condition (drooping or burn)
Water as needed to maintain optimal moisture levels
Create a foliar feed solution and evenly apply to the raspberry leaves
** Identify primocanes (green, thick stems) and floricanes (silvering, brittle) to differentiate between first-year and second-year growth.
** Recognize the ripening cycle of different varieties (early spring, late spring/summer, late summer/fall) to plan pruning and harvesting.
** Choose between summer-bearing, autumn-bearing, or everbearing raspberries based on desired harvest times.
** Cut down old floricanes near the base in winter to make way for new growth.
** Stake new primocane growth to support their vertical development and protect berries from ground contact.
** Check soil moisture by observing leaf condition (drooping or burn) to determine when watering is needed.
** Water regularly to maintain optimal soil moisture levels, adjusting based on observed conditions.
** Create a foliar feed solution and apply it to the leaves using a sprayer or similar tool to provide essential nutrients.
